cmCourseInfo.description: This is the language course to take if you have had no previous experience of the German language. The emphasis is on comprehension, speaking, reading, writing, vocabulary and basic grammar. This course can be counted towards all programs in German. Note: Students with any previous knowledge of German are REQUIRED to take a placement test offered at the department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to German I
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Senior high school German or equivalent. Note: Students with any previous knowledge of German are required to take a placement test offered at the department.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is for students with no prior background in German. Any student with any background or knowledge of the German languages is REQUIRED to take a placement test, which is a written test which takes thirty minutes. It takes place at the German Department, 50 St. Joseph St., (at Bay St./wing of St. Basil's Church), Odette Hall, 3rd Floor. Office is room 322. To arrange for a placement test, please email gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is intended for students with some prior knowledge of German. It is equivalent to the Spring Term of GER100Y1. The emphasis is on comprehension, speaking, reading, writing, vocabulary and basic grammar.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to German
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Senior high school German or equivalent. GER100Y.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is for students with some background in German. You are required to take a 30 minute written placement test to determine your level. The German Department must enrol you in this course. To register for the test, please contact gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca. The placement test takes place at the German Department, 50 St. Joseph St., (at Bay St/wing of St. Basil's Church), Odette Hall, 3rd Floor.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is for Graduate Students wishing to take Introduction to German I. You must get your Add/Drop dates from from your home department signed and brought to the German Department for signature. Email the German Department if you have any questions at gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course taught in English is intended for students who are unfamiliar with German culture. It examines historical, political and cultural developments in Germany from about 1871 to the present focusing on literary and non-literary texts. Note: This course is required for the major and specialist program, and can only be taken within the first two years. In later years it may be substituted with GER310H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to German Culture (E)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
If you are taking GER 150HS, you are required to register for one of the tutorials. Course will be taught in English.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: September 6, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: This course continues the work done in GER100Y1 / GER101H1. It further expands on basic grammar and vocabulary, practice in comprehension, composition, and conversation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to German II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: GER100Y1/GER101H1 or German placement test, Senior high school German or equivalent

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers a transition from the language courses to the topic courses on the 300-level. It introduces students to German literature and provides them with working methods and analytical tools relevant for the study of German literary texts in the original German. Note: This course is required for the major and specialist program
cmCourseInfo.title: German Literature I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in German.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course taught in English offers a general survey introducing major dramatic works from the German-speaking countries from the eighteenth century to the present, by authors such as G.E. Lessing, F. Schiller, G. Büchner, B. Brecht, P. Weiss and E. Jelinek.
cmCourseInfo.title: German Drama in Translation (E)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in English

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Day and Time Change (Fall Term): September 17, 2018. Room Change: September 17, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces Yiddish language, literature, music, theater, and cinema through interactive multi-media seminars, designed to build proficiency in reading, writing and comprehending. No prior knowledge of Yiddish is required.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Yiddish

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Please note that the course meets on different days and times for the Fall and Winter Sessions. Fall term meets Wednesdays 2-4pm and Fridays 2-3pm. Winter term meets Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays 2-3pm.

cmCourseInfo.description: This is an introductory course to the thought of Karl Marx, Friedrich Nietzsche, and Sigmund Freud and their pioneering contributions to the understanding of the individual and society in modernity. Readings include selections from writings of the early Marx, the Communist Manifesto, and Capital, Nietzsche's critique of culture, academe, and nationalism, and Freud's theory of culture, his views on the psychopathology of everyday life, on the meaning of dreams, symptoms, the return of the repressed, and what it might mean to live in a free society.
cmCourseInfo.title: Marx, Nietzsche, Freud (E)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in English

cmCourseInfo.description: The movement of cultural products, material goods, capital, people, ideas, and information across national borders has resulted in a new quality of global interdependency. The course explores the contemporary character of globalization patterns and problems as they bear on German-speaking contexts. Readings in globalization history and theory.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Issues - German Contexts

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in English.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: September 6, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: Continuing the work done in GER100Y1 and GER200Y1, this course offers German at the intermediate level focusing on extension of vocabulary, specific problems of grammar, essay-writing, reading and conversation. The Department reserves the right to place students in the appropriate course in the series GER200Y1 and GER300Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate German

cmCourseInfo.description: Building on the work of GER205H1, this course offers a survey of German literature and culture from the eighteenth to the twentieth century. Within a chronological framework, students read and analyze excerpts from representative works of major German writers. Note: This course is required for the major and specialist program, and should be taken concurrently with GER300Y1
cmCourseInfo.title: German Literature II

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in German.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on contemporary German culture as expressed through a variety of media. It approaches Germany and Germany's position within Europe and the world mainly (but not exclusively) through non-literary texts. Note: This course may count as a substitute course for the required GER150H1; please inquire in advance.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary German Culture and Media

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in German.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: August 22, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on German authors of the nineteenth century. Literary, political and philosophical texts are analyzed as a discussion of political uprisings, the industrial revolution and the emergence of German nationalism.
cmCourseInfo.title: 19th Century German Literature

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in German

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: January 30 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of post-World War II German literature and culture from Zero Hour through to present-day debates about the Holocaust and its memorialization within a German context.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing Memory: Post 1945

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in German

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers an introduction and exploration of German poetry from all ages. The focus lies on poems which pick as a central topic the self in its relation to itself, others, and society.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to German Poetry

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in German.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Day changed: June 28, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: In this course, we examine literary and cinematic explorations of bioethical questions, in order to understand how artistic discourse approaches problems such as normality, madness, and biopower. Readings could include texts by G. Buechner, H. Kleist, E.T.A. Hoffmann, F. Kafka, and T. Mann, among others. All material will be read in English translation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Narratives of the Body (E)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in English

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: January 16 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: The course offers close reading, rehearsing and staging of a play. Students will become familiar with the different steps of a theater production, be introduced to basic acting and staging techniques and get acquainted to leading theories of theater.
cmCourseInfo.title: German Theater Production

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: June 7, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: This course presents students with a survey of the history and development of the German cinema. It examines major trends of German cinematography focusing on thematic and formal aspects.
cmCourseInfo.title: German Visual Cultures (formerly GER351H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in German.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course conducted in Yiddish offers a review of basic grammar, stylistics, study of short literary texts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Yiddish

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: September 19, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the major figures and tendencies in modern Yiddish literature and culture from the beginning of the 19th century to the present. Readings (in English) of modern Yiddish prose, poetry, drama and cinema.
cmCourseInfo.title: Yiddish Literature in Translation (E)

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides students with a working knowledge of German business culture that allows them to navigate the German workplace. The main focus is to deepen students’ knowledge of business concepts. Note: This course is required for the minor program in Business German
cmCourseInfo.title: German Business Culture 1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in German

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers an intensive development of the linguistic skills needed in the context of business transactions and management in German-speaking countries. Through materials from various sources, students develop oral and written skills for competence in German business communication as well as cross-cultural awareness.
cmCourseInfo.title: German Business Culture 2

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in German.

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a course for advanced learners of German reviewing complex features of the language and introducing them to aspects of German stylistics. The emphasis lies on oral and written communication.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced German

cmCourseInfo.description: This course taught in English offers an examination of key moments and themes in German intellectual history from the Enlightenment to the present.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in German Intellectual History (E)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Advanced status: permission of the department

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in English

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to the literature and some philosophical tenets of Romanticism (roughly 1798-1830) as a critical engagement with Enlightenment, modern science, and modernity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Romanticism

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is taught in German.

courses.name: Topics in German Literature and Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: An open course which explores specific aspects of German literature and culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in German Literature and Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: This course conducted entirely in Yiddish focuses on advanced reading, writing, vocabulary and conversation, the study of poetry, short fiction, and memoir literature by leading authors. Selected advanced grammatical topics are presented in conjunction with the study of texts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Yiddish

cmCourseInfo.description: A reading & research project in Germanic literature and/or culture involving a substantive research component. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Study
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Advanced status: permission of the department. Note: permission needs to be obtained by May 1st for the Fall Term and by Nov. 1st for the Spring Term

cmCourseInfo.description: A scholarly project chosen by the student and supervised by a member of the staff. The form of the project and the manner of its execution are determined in consultation with the supervisor. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Individual Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Advanced status: permission of the department. Note: project proposals need to be submitted by June 1st
